first_story_block:
Your name is Arakhan.


For years, you have dreamed of becoming Captain of the Guard, and protecting your small hometown of Lyestra. Fortunately for you, your wildest dreams came true just last week. You finally received your long overdue promotion, and now you are the official Captain of the Guard!


Lyestra is a quiet enough village, so the first few weeks were rather uneventful. However, two days ago, you received a tip that a group of goblin warriors had been spotted camping out in the woods not far from Lyestra. Goblins rarely come so near to a village, so you and a handful of other men have gone to scope out the situation. So far, you have found nothing. You are running low on supplies, and the men have requested to return to Lyestra.


However, you told them you would like to make one last sweep of the area before you return home. You and your men have split up to search the area for any sign of the goblins.


You are on your own, in a dense area of the woods. You are searching for any sign that the goblins were here.

action_results.result:
You get on your hands and knees, hoping to find a clue underneath a nearby bush, but alas, all you get for your trouble is a dirty uniform. There is nothing to be found under the bush. You stand up quickly, trying best as you can to brush the filth from your clothes.


What now?

As you stare at the tree, you notice something that had escaped your search before. There appears to be an arrowhead embedded in the trunk of the tree. You yank it out. It seems that it was once attached to an arrow, but someone has snapped off the shaft, leaving just the arrowhead. There is a small white feather attached to the arrowhead. You pull it off. It appears to be decorated with a strange symbol, the likes of which you have never seen before. A red, two headed cobra has been painted onto the feather. The symbol fills you with dread.

action_results.action: Place the feather in your pocket
action_results.result: You feel that you've seen all you can here. You turn, ready to go back to your camp, when suddenly you hear a quick rustling in the bushes. You feel sweat instantly bead on your brow. Someone is coming towards you, and they're moving quickly. What will you do?

action_results.action: Wait to see who it is
action_results.result:
You stand at the ready, but keep your sword sheathed. A good thing, too, because at that moment, Adonis, official messenger of Lyestra, comes hurtling through the bushes.


"Arakhan!!" He nearly collapses to the ground with relief and exhaustion. "Thank the gods I've found you!"


Adonis is panting heavily. He bends over, trying to catch his breath.


"Calm down," you say, "What seems to be the problem? What are you doing so far from Lyestra?"


"Lyestra?" Adonis gets a hollow, far off look in his eyes. "Lyestra is...now don't take this too hard, but--" he swallows. "Lyestra is gone."


You nearly sink to your knees. Lyestra? Your home town, gone?


"What do you mean? Tell me, NOW!" You are barely able to choke back your panic and grief. Your village needs you now more than ever. Now is the time to keep a cool head.


"Goblins came in the night---we---we weren't ready for them," Adonis chokes, "And so many of them! They just kept coming! In hordes! I barely got out with my own--I mean--I fought off at least half a dozen, of course--but---even for someone like me, I knew the odds were hopeless--"


"Get to the point," you growl, "How many are dead?"


Adonis stares down at the ground.


"....Hundreds," he mumbles.


Now, you really do fall to your knees. How could you have let this happen? You've failed Lyestra, and nearly a hundred people have paid for your carelessness with their lives. You've failed your guards--your guards! You have to find them. They must be scattered around the woods--somewhere nearby. You have to find them before a troop of goblins finds them first!


"We've got to get back to Lyestra," Adonis continues, "There might be a few survivors left. And we have to find out who was responsible for the attack!"


You weigh your options. If you go with Adonis now, the two of you could conceivably make it back to Lyestra in two hours. However, there are still a few guards doing their final sweep of the area. They could take care of themselves, surely, but you would feel much better knowing that they are safe in this uncertain time.


Adonis looks at you expectantly. What will it be? Find your guard regiment? Or go back to Lyestra and search for survivors?

You decide to return to Lyestra with Adonis.

"The smart choice," Adonis nods.

You feel awful about abandoning your guard regiment, but time is of the essence. And, after all, your friends are trained warriors. You hope they will be able to find their way back on their own.

You follow the winding path, Adonis tagging along, until at last you reach the town gates.

And there, your blood runs cold.


You reach the Lyestra gates, and stop in abject horror. The town has been completely gutted.

Smoke billows from the wreckage of houses. You hear wailing in the streets.

Corpses line the streets, and a few wanderers roam freely, searching and crying out for their loved ones.

Never before have you felt like such a failure.

"HALT!" A voice cries, "Who goes there?!"

You raise your head and see a short, stocky man in a helmet approach you.

It's Quent, one of your guards.

"Quent!!" You cry, "It's me, Arakhan."

"And me!!! Adonis!!!" Adonis screams.

"We've returned," you say.

Quent lowers his spear and begins to cry, his brave front completely lost.

"Oh, Arakhan," he sobs, and wraps his arms around you. "You're back!! It was---it was a living nightmare...."

"Where are the other guards?" you ask, gripping him by the shoulders. "Where are the others we left posted here?"

He sobs, choking.

"All dead, Arakhan," he cries.

"Brutus? Carissa? Andrey?" You ask.

"All of them!! They were cut down, every last one. Killian forced me to hide so someone would be left to tell you what happened. I ran, only to see him get shot down as well. Arakhan, they came at us like a wave of death."

"Stand tall, Quent," you say. "I've come to kill the one responsible for this."

"I'm so glad you're back," he sobs. "Please, head into the town and see what you can do for the villagers. They need someone. And maybe you can find some of the answers you need in there."

You nod, and release Quent to return to his patrol duties.

Adonis approaches you.

"Well, I hope you're satisfied," he grumbles, "Some protection."

"Move along, Adonis," you growl, and he yelps.

"Erk! I--uh--right, then. I'll be on my way," he mumbles, and shuffles off into the city.

You glare, watching him go.

After a moment, and a chance to catch your breath....you enter the city gates as well.

At long last, you are home.

Home.


Or what remains of it.


You wander through the streets of Lyestra, barely even recognizable after such brutal destruction. There is the old tree that you used to swing from as a child, burned and splintered into nothing more than a husk. The mayor's house looms in the distance, black smoke plumes rising from it and lifting into the sky.


Worst of all are the bodies.


You cannot tear your gaze away from the corpses lining the streets, the sobbing that wracks every alleyway, and the stench of hot blood and fire that fills the air.


You see not a few familiar faces among the dead, and, nearly choking on your grief, you press on.


Eventually, you find that you have traversed the length of the entire village, and you now stand at the North Gate.


The great wall that surrounds your village has been cracked, and furniture and lumber has been haphazardly barricaded into the broken sections.


The Gate itself is wrapped deeply in chains, with an enormous bronze padlock sealing the chains tight.


A man staggers over to you, his eyes glinting malevolently. It's Joad, one of the older guards on your force. He holds a pitchfork, and is staggering towards you.


"ARAKHAN!" he shouts. You feel a flutter of nervous fear.

You draw your sword, and hold it out protectively.


Joad snorts.


"Useless AND stupid," he mutters. "Who would have guessed?"


You lower your sword, feeling a hot rush of embarrassment. Joad sneers, his pitchfork falling to his side.


"Welcome back, Captain," he grunts. You feel his hatred wash over you like the tide. "Have a nice walk out in the woods, then? Don't mind us, we were just out here, fighting for our lives while you hid in the bushes."


"Calm down, Joad," you say, "I'm back now, and I swear to you, I will have revenge on these miserable creatures."


Joad spits.


"Fat lotta good that'll do us now," he mutters, "Now that near the whole village's dead and killed." He sighs, and you see weariness crease his brow.


"If you want to go and play the hero....and get your damned self killed--be my guest," Joad grumbles, "we were barely able to fight them back. They left for the woods---we thought to go find you. But just an hour or so ago, our scouts saw them returning. They've made camp just north of here, probably planning their next move."


"Do you see who is out there?" you ask.


"We didn't see nothing," Joad growls, "You prob'ly know more than we do. All we know is that we was having a normal day, when suddenly a horde of goblins tear through this town like wildfire, killin' and maimin'. We barely fought 'em back."


You reach for the padlock on the North Gate. "I'll bring you their leader's head," you growl, gripping your sword.


"Ah, ah, ah," Joad says, staying your hand. I'd love to see you go out there and get killed much as the next man. But that lock ain't comin' off. Not 'less you get a key for it."


"You don't have a key?" you ask.


"Not me," Joad says, "we gave out keys to people we trust, people who were here."


"I get it," you say.


"Go on and explore the town a bit. See what you left behind. Find a key. When you get one, come back here, and I'll let you through. But not a moment before."


You nod. "Very well," you say.


You turn and leave the North Gate behind, heading for the Lyestra Town Square. Your mission is clear.


Find a key.

Then, take your vengeance.

action_results.action: Go to the Lyestra Town Square
action_results.result:
You stand in the Town Square of Lyestra.


The enormous stone fountain of Lyestra stands before you. It is cracked down the center, and stained with blood. At this time of day, it would normally be gushing happily, but now, it stands still and silent, like an enormous gravestone.


You think for a moment. Your mission is to find a key, exit through the North Gate, and take your revenge on the monsters responsible for this attack.


But perhaps you should explore the town a bit. Not only will you be likely to find a key, you may also find more information you can use to defeat the mysterious attackers.


You consider your options. There is the Morgan's bar--a popular (well, really the only) tavern in town. The few survivors of the attack are almost certain to be holed up there.


The Mayor's house is smoking in the distance. It might be a good idea to check there, to see if he or any of his family survived the attack.


And lastly, there is the Lyestra Library. The Library is rather large for such a small village, and the Librarian is a good friend of yours. Perhaps you will find some information on your attackers there.


Where to go first?

You weigh your options, and decide the best course of action is to head to the esteemed Morgan's Bar.


You head down the winding pathways of Lyestra, until you have reached the swinging double doors of the Bar.


You push through the door, and there, as you expected, you see several dozen villagers, all crowded about within the dimly lit tavern.

They are gathered around the small wooden tables, drinking at the bar. A few children are huddled in the corner, smeared with dirt and playing a card game in grim silence.


The Morgan's Bar, being the largest building in town, was always designated as the survival shelter in case of attack. It had almost been a sort of joke. 'We'll drink til' the invaders get bored,' people used to say, laughing.

After all, who would ever want to attack a town as tiny and insignificant as Lyestra?


You shake your thoughts away, and stride into the Bar.


Everyone freezes for a moment at your approach, and all eyes turn to stare directly at you. You feel their gazes burning into you.


And then, quickly, the villagers all turn aside, quickly absorbed back into whatever menial tasks had been consuming them.


You feel a hot rush of shame, but force it down. You have a mission--you must find a key to unlock the door.

Someone in here is sure to have it.

You survey the room.

There are the children, of course, playing their game in the corner. Morgan himself, the Barkeep, is washing a glass and avoids your gaze. There is an incredibly muscular man in the corner, picking at his teeth with a dagger, and wrapping a gauze bandage around the his arm. And in the corner, there is a tall, gaunt man in a purple cloak. His hood is up, so you can't make out his face in the dimly lit room.

And of course, you could always have a drink.

"Morgan!" You call, and start walking towards him.


He sees you out of the corner of his eye, and turns away from you, to help a customer.


"And how can I help you, miss?" he asks, pointedly ignoring you. Your hand falters, and you turn away from him.


Clearly, he is none too happy to see you. Time for a different approach.

You are standing in the middle of the Morgan's Bar, surrounded by the few survivors of the attack.


There are some children, playing a game in the corner.


Morgan stands behind the bar, washing glasses.


A muscular man is bandaging himself near a table.


There is a cloaked man in the shadows.


And you are pretty parched.

You walk towards the Muscular Man.


He sneers as you approach.

"Wellll, well, WELL!" he rumbles, his scarred face leering down at you, "Look at the little guard captain, come snivlin' back."


He is wrapping a gauze bandage around his arm. He appears to have sustained a nasty cut along his bicep.


You recognize the man as soon as you approach. It's none other than Riker, local mischief maker and brawler. You've had a few run-ins with him before.


"Riker," you say, curtly.


"Thought you'd never show your face 'round this town again, runt," Riker growls, "Or worse, I was tellin' evry'one I figgered YOU were in league with them goblins."


"They tricked us all," you say, "But they're going to pay for what they've done."


Riker lets out a wet, throaty laugh.


"I'll bet they will!!" he croaks. His voice sounds like a bag of wet marbles. "You go'wan and get your head cut off by 'em, thank a lot, then, cap, that'll show 'em, yeah."


"I plan to face them," you say, "But I need a key to open the North Ga--"


Riker spits.


"Well bloody well good luck with that," he says, "cause you ain't gettin' no help from me."


He turns away, finished with the conversation, and goes back to his bandage.

You walk over to the strange man in the purple cloak.


As you get closer, you see that it is no stranger at all, but your good friend, and second-in-command, Lodan!


He stands as you approach.


"Ah, Captain," he says, nodding serenely, "I see you've finally made it to the Bar. Have a seat."

You wrap your arms around Lodan, and pull him in tightly, nearly crushing him in a bear hug.


"Captain, I--er---ah--erkkkr," he says.


You don't let go.


Everyone in the bar turns to stare.


It gets uncomfortable, but you've committed to this, and it would be even more awkward to end it now.


Finally, you release him. The two of you stand there in silence for a few moments.


"Please do not do that again, sir," Lodan says.

You take a seat across from Lodan, and the two of you have a long conversation about the invasion, and where to go next from here.


"I've been searching town, and neither Glusen nor Anaria have shown up yet," he mutters. "I fear that they might still be out in the woods somewhere. Or worse. The sun is already about to set. They should have been back by now."


"Actually, Lodan, about that--" you say, but you are suddenly interrupted by an incredible crashing sound coming from behind you. You both turn, and see the muscular man in the corner screaming at a young woman for having knocked over his beer. She has begun to cry, and spit is flying from the man's mouth.


"Riker," Lodan sighs, shaking his head, "Of all villagers, of course HE had to be one to survive." Lodan looks up. "Apologies, that was cruel," he says, "I suppose we must all be allies now."


"I'm going to need as much help as I can get," you say, "especially since I've got to find a key to the North Gate."


"A key?" Lodan asks. He points at Morgan, who is working behind the bar. "You mean like that one there?"


You double-take. Morgan clearly has a key tied around his neck. You can't believe you didn't notice it before! What's more, it looks exactly the right size and shape to fit the North Gate.


"That's got to be it," you say, "I'd better go get it."


"Careful, there," Lodan says, "Morgan was none too friendly to me, and I doubt he will be any different to you."


"What shall I do?" you ask.


"Well, Morgan has never turned down a paying customer, even one he despised," Lodan says, "Keep that in mind." He stands up.

"Well, I'm going to be off," he says, "Maybe I'll find more of our friends."


You nod, and say your farewells to Lodan. He exits through the Tavern doors.

You are standing in the middle of the Morgan's Bar, surrounded by the few survivors of the attack.


There are some children, playing a game in the corner.


Morgan stands behind the bar, washing glasses.


A muscular man is bandaging himself near a table.


And you are pretty parched.

A drink, maybe that's what you need.


You take a few steps towards the bar, and stop instantly.


You have no money on you.


Embarrassed, you return to the bar.

You wander over to the kids. They seem to be playing some strange sort of card game.


A boy with dark eyes and darker hair stares up at you as you approach. The other children look to him as though he were their leader.


"Hello, children," you say, extending a hand in what you hope is a friendly way.


"Hello," the little boy says.


"I'm looking for something," you say, "And I'm wondering if you could help."


"Mum says not to talk to strangers," a little girl hisses to the boy.


"Yeh, well, where's your mum now?" the boy asks.


The girl looks down at the floor, and tugs at the hem of her dress.


"That's right," the boy says, "we ain't got no more rules to follow, now." He looks back up at you. "What you want, then?"


You inhale slowly.


"I'm looking for a key," you say.


"Ain't got no key," the boy says, but then he reconsiders. "But on the other hand, I DO got this." He holds up a shiny copper coin.


"A coin?" you say.


"It's lucky," the dark-haired boy says solemnly. "I'll play you for it, if'n you want."


"Hm," you say, "Well, I don't have anything to play for. I've got no money on me."


"Yes you do," the boy says, and he slowly points a finger at your sword, hooked onto your belt. "I'll play you for that." He looks up slowly, giving you a toothsome grin. "What say ya?"

"Alright," you say, ignoring your better judgment. "Let's play."


"Ha!" the boys says, "Alright then. Here's how we do."


He lays out a row of cards, seven in total.


"You gotta win three rounds if you want the coin."


You are facing the boy.


"From your left to right, the cards are---1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6, 7." He says. He lifts the cards to show you the numbers. "Got that?"


You nod.


"Alright," he says. "Now I'm gonna mix 'em up."


And he does.


He takes the third card, and moves it two spaces to your right.

Then, he moves the seventh card two spaces to your left.

Now, he moves the new seventh card all the way to position 1, making it the farthest card on your left.

He takes the new seventh card, and moves it two spaces to his right.

Then, he takes the second card, and moves it one space to your right.



He looks up at you.

"Now tell me," he says, "In which position is the card with the number '5' on it?"

"Oooooh, bad luck, then!" he laughs, and flips up the card, showing you that you've made the wrong choice.


You sigh deeply.


"Alright, now," he says, "Give me my prize!!"


"Absolutely not," you say, "Swords are not for children."


"Liar!!! No fair!!" He starts to cry, and the other children start to cry as well. It's causing a scene.


"Oh, alright!" You say, "You can hold it, for a minute, at least." You hand him your sword.


"Whoa, COOL!" He says, he whirls around with the sword, spinning faster and faster as he grows more excited.


"Now careful," you say, "Swords are very--"


That's all you can get out before the sword slips from his grasp, flies through the air and severs your head instantaneously.


The children all scream as your headless corpse sprays blood everywhere.


What a dumb way to die.

"That one," you say, pointing at Card 6.


He lifts it, showing you the number "5." He sticks his tongue out at you.


"Lucky," he whines. "But that's just the first round."


He reaches in his pocket and takes out another deck of cards.


"This is my lucky deck," he says, "we'll see how good you are now."


He lays out seven cards.


"From your left to right," he says, "The cards are: Phoenix, Monkey, Snake, Dragon, Troll, Ogre, and Goblin."


You nod. "I'm ready," you say.


He starts to shift the cards.


He moves the first card three spaces to his left.

Then, he moves the second card two spaces to your right.

He takes the seventh card and moves it five spaces to your left.

He takes the fourth card and moves it one space to your right.

He takes the sixth card, and moves it two spaces to his right.

Then, he takes all seven cards, keeping them in a row, and spins the entire row clockwise, so the row is now upside down.



"Which card has the dragon?" he asks.

"Card 5," you say.


The dark-eyed boy's eyes grow darker.


He smolders as he lifts the card, showing you the face of the Dragon.


"Fine," he says, muttering, "But now you have to win the third round, and it ain't gonna be easy."


He lays out seven cards.


"This time I'm gonna mix decks," he says.


He shows you the cards. "From your left to right, they are, Card 2, Dragon, Ogre, Card 6, Card 1, Monkey, and Card 5."


He slams the cards down in front of you.


"Ready?" he asks. You nod.


He moves the first card three spaces to your right.

He then moves the sixth card two spaces to your left.

He moves the new first card one space to his left.

He takes the entire row, and flips it clockwise, then counterclockwise, then clockwise again.

He moves the fourth card two spaces to his left, then one to your right, then two to his right.

He covers the cards with his arms and moves them around a little bit. He doesn't let you see.

He realizes there are now eight cards, and takes one of them off the ground at random, ripping it up.

He moves the second card one space to your left.


"Where is the Ogre?" he asks.

You point at his sleeve.


"You think I would cheat??" he asks. He shows you his sleeves. Empty. He sticks his tongue out at you.


"Nyeh. So there," he says, "Now pick a real card, dummy."

Embarrassed at being bested by a child, you randomly pick a card without really thinking about it.


"Um, card 4 I guess?" You say.

action_results.action: Point at the Girl next to him
action_results.result:
You point at the little girl sitting next to him.


She immediately burst into tears.


"I told you, Joffa!!" she says, "I told you we shouldn't cheat!!!" She hands you the Ogre card, which had been secretly tucked inside her dress pocket the entire time.


Joffa, the dark-haired boy, slams a fist into the ground angrily.


"And I told YOU not to give the game away, Leesey!!" His face is red, but he reluctantly hands over his copper coin.


"There you go, sir," he says, frowning.


You take the coin.


You now have one (1) copper coin.


Unbelievable riches are now yours.


You head back to the main bar area.

You are standing in the middle of the Morgan's Bar, surrounded by the few survivors of the attack.


Morgan stands behind the bar, washing glasses.


A muscular man is bandaging himself near a table.


And you are pretty parched.

The bar is pretty crowded, but you find an open seat and quickly snag it.


Before Morgan can say anything to you, you've laid your copper coin down on the table.


"Pour me a drink, eh Morgan?" you ask.


As he gets closer, you can see a key tied around his neck on a string. It has to be the North Gate key, you're sure of it.


"What'll you have?" he grumbles. He's clearly angry with you.


What will you have?

"Comin' right up," Morgan says. He reaches under the bar, and pours you a drink.


As he leans forward, the key around his neck swings enticingly.


Now is your chance--and it may be your only chance.

You yank the key from around Morgan's neck. The string snaps instantly, and the key is in your hand!!


"Hey!!" Morgan shouts, but it's too late. You start to run, away from the bar, towards the double doors!


They get closer--closer---


Then---


BAM!!


You've slammed into a full blown mountain of meat, stopped dead in your tracks, inches from the door.


It's the muscular man with the arm wound--Riker, local troublemaker and scoundrel.


"Well, WELL," he says, "A Coward, AND a thief!"


"Please," you say, "I have to get out of here. I'm going to avenge us all."


"HA!" Riker sneers, "fat chance." He raises a fist. "How about I POUND YOU INTO THE GROUND, instead?!?!" He raises his beefy arm in the air, and the entire bar cheers loudly, excited for your demise.


No choice, looks like you're gonna have to fight!

Riker circles you, angrily, his bloodshot eyes watching your every movement.


He's determined not to let you leave this bar, and you're going to have to incapacitate him.


You watch him as he strafes you, and get the sinking feeling that taking on a bear might have been a wiser option.


Your mind races. Is it better to wait for him to lunge? Or should you strike now, try to catch him off guard?

You move quickly. Riker is a mountain of a man, but you're much lighter on your feet. You strike hard, going straight for his gut.


You grin as your blow connects!


Unfortunately, the blow is practically absorbed by his granite-hard abs.


He laughs down at you.


"That was your best shot?" He sneers. He grabs you by the hair and hoists you up. "My turn."


Grabbing you by the hair and neck, he hurls you across the bar!


The onlookers gasp in shock as you go crashing into a table, smashing it to splinters.


You're dizzy but you pull yourself back to your feet, and soon you're sprinting towards him at full force.


Riker readies himself for your next attack.


What will you do?

You slam a fist towards Riker, but he's prepared and protected for your attack.


His hands quickly rise, blocking your attack. You wince in pain as your fist slams against his blocked arms.


"Enough of this nonsense," Riker spits. "I thought you might be some kind of CHALLENGE. Guess I was wrong."


And then he rears his fist back and socks you in the face.


You feel like you got trampled by a wild stallion. Your world spins, you take several stumbling steps to the left, then to the right, before falling to a heap.


Your head bangs against a nearby table as you go down, and the world goes dark.


"Heh. Take THAT, Arakhan," Riker leers, coming over to your still form. He looks down at your body, and notices a pool of blood spreading from beneath your unmoving figure.


"Uh," Riker says, grimacing, "Arakhan?"

action_results.action: Sweep Riker's legs out from under him
action_results.result:
You use your momentum to slide across the floor just as you reach Riker.


He was preparing himself for a blow, and is thrown off guard as you hit the ground. Your legs sweep out, utilizing an attack you learned in your guard training--an attack specifically designed to topple larger foes.


Riker howls as your legs smash into his ankles, and he goes down, hard.


The glasses on the shelves rattle as Riker slams into the floor.


He swears and shouts, quickly trying to pull himself onto his feet.


The two of you are on the floor, both quickly scrambling for purchase.


Quick, what now?!

action_results.action: Try to stand up before Riker does
action_results.result:
The two of you scramble to your feet, panting heavily, trying to gain the upper ground.


However, the two of you are evenly matched, and soon, you are both standing at opposite points of the bar--circling and staring each other down.


Looks like you've just ended up right back where you started. Gonna have to try another tactic to take this guy down.

action_results.action: Grab a nearby table cloth to pull yourself up
action_results.result:
You see a low hanging table cloth and wrap your hands around it, attempting to yank yourself upwards.


You failed to realize, however, that the table was fully set.


As soon as you grab the table cloth, everything--glasses, cutlery, plates, bowls--and a large iron kettle--go flying.


Riker pulls himself to his feet, just as the kettle arcs through the air, smacking him directly in the forehead.


"AGHH!!!!" He screams. The kettle left an angry red gash across his head, and blood is leaking down into his eyes. He stumbles wildly, grabbing at anything, before losing his balance and crashing into a wall.


"YOU LITTLE CHEAT!!" Riker shrieks.


"Now, then," you say, "If you'll just surrender, I think we can all--"


"SURRENDER THIS!!" Riker says, running at you with a knife.


Oh dear.

Riker is running towards you with a knife!


Things are looking pretty dire.


Quick, do something!

You try, but you aren't fast enough. Riker's knife plunges into you, and the world goes red.


People are screaming, and your last, faint hope is that Riker will receive justice for his madness.

You only have just enough time to jab two fingers into Riker's right arm as he slashes--


--And your fingers strike right into Riker's arm wound.


In agony, he drops the knife, gripping his arm in pain.


You notice that Riker's bandage--the one tightly bound around his right arm--is slowly unraveling. Interesting.


Riker is going for his knife, a few feet away from him on the floor.


You've got to do something, and fast.

action_results.action: Try to grab the knife before Riker
action_results.result:
You and Riker both sprint towards the knife, each lunging at the same moment--!


But Riker just barely beats you to it, grabbing it and raising it malevolently.


You are very close to Riker now--you might be able to do something before he attacks again.

action_results.action: Grab the loose end of bandage
action_results.result:
You yank the loose end of Riker's bandage and it gives a bit. Riker recoils in pain, giving you the chance to put some distance between the two of you.


You are now holding the end of Riker's bandage.


It stretches out across the bar, still connected to his arm.


"Hey!" He shouts, "Give that back!!"


What will you do?

action_results.action: Pull on the bandage as hard as you can
action_results.result:
You attempt it, but Riker sees your attack coming.


He slashes at the bandage with his knife, leaving you holding nothing but a useless scrap of fabric.


"Nice try," Riker says.


The next target his knife finds is you.

"Oh," you say, dangling your end of the bandage tauntingly, "You mean this old thing?"


Riker runs at you in a fury, not even caring that he is still connected to you.


The two of you sprint around the bar. You make sure to get the bandage tangled around small tables, chairs, and shelves.


Finally, you are too winded to run anymore.


Riker corners you.


"LET'S FINISH THIS, PIPSQUEAK!!" he screams, showering you with spit.


He raises his knife high into the air........

action_results.action: Tie the loose end of the bandage around a sturdy table
action_results.result:
Riker swings his arm--


--Forgetting that his arm is now tangled across the entire bar.


As he lunges at you, the bandage becomes taut, and he is yanked backwards by the force of his own inertia. He goes down hard, clocking his head against the hard wooden floor.


You stand over his unconscious body, looking down at him.


He's out cold.


"Order up," you say, quietly.


Everyone in the bar is confused for a moment, then they all burst into cheers.


"Riker sucks!" Somebody yells.


You grin as everyone cheers for you, even Morgan, who is only mildly upset that a good portion of his bar was destroyed in the brawl.


"Go ahead and keep that key," Morgan says, "I'd say you've more than earned it."


Everyone gives you high fives on your way through the doors.


As you exit the bar into the dying twilight, it is with the proud knowledge that you have fought well.


And yet--your true fight has not even begun.

You finally have a key that will open the Northern Gate.


There's no time to delay. You've promised to avenge your village, and avenge it you shall.


You know that the ones who destroyed your town--the goblins, and their leaders--are all camped just beyond the Northern Gate.


It might be suicide to try to face them alone, but you know you have no choice.


If you don't assassinate their leader tonight, they will surely regroup and finish the job of destroying Lyestra tomorrow.


You steel your courage, and then head towards the Northern Gate to face Joad.

You grip the key firmly in your hand, and approach the Northern Gate, just as the sun sets over the horizon.


Joad is leaning against the wall, and watches you coolly as you approach.


"Well?" he asks.


You hold up the key. Joad nods.


"Well, well," he acquiesces, "looks like you got one, after all."


Joad takes the key from you and slides it into the heavy iron padlock that keeps the gate seal.


With a K-THUNK, the padlock falls away, and the chains loosen. Joad tugs on the chains as he speaks.


"I don't know who you convinced to give you that key," Joad says, "But I'm going to tell you the truth."


The chains fall away, and the wrought iron Northern Gate swings open with an ominous creeeeak.


Joad points out, through the Gate.


"Out there," he says, "Out there is the northern hill country. We know that the goblins are camped out in a huge horde out there, somewhere in the hills. Figure their leader is out there, too. They've been quiet since the morning, so they must be biding their time for something. None of us are dumb enough to think they've had their fill of destruction."


Joad suddenly grabs your arm, as though he's pulling you back from the brink of a cliff.


"Are you really planning on going out there alone?" he asks, "I want you to know. It's suicide."


"What choice do we have?" you ask, "With the exception of you, me, and three or four guards, everyone else who could defend this town is dead. And like you said, it's suicide. I'm not putting anyone else in danger. Maybe it's futile. Maybe not. But either I go out there and fight, or I wait here to be killed. And I choose to fight."


Joad releases your arm, and you can see something like a glimmer of admiration in his eyes.


"Well, I'll never let it be said that Arakhan of Lyestra was a coward." He chuckles. "An idiot, maybe. But not a coward."


"Goodbye, Joad," you say.


"Goodbye, Arakhan," he says, "Until we meet again."

Alright. This is it. Everything you've done up to this point has led up to this moment.


The sun has set, blanketing the hill country in a cover of darkness.


The clouds are thick in the sky, blocking the stars. You're thankful for small favors.


Even though the sun has only just set, nearly everything is in pitch darkness. You can make out the shapes of the hills before you. The ground curves up and down. Wind whips the grass at your feet. Everything feels ominous.


This is crazy, you think to yourself, Absolutely insane.


You shake yourself out of it, pulling your thoughts together. You go over your plan, crude as it is.


First, you'll sneak your way through the tall grass, and through the northern hills. Goblins are loud, clumsy, and messy, making them incredibly easy to track, particularly for someone as skilled in tracking as yourself.


You figure you'll be able to find their encampment quite easily.


Once you've found their base, you'll be able to figure out more. And then you'll wait, hidden, outside their encampment. They may be a large force, but you've played and lived in these hills since you were a little boy. You know all the hiding places that they would never find.


And then you'll wait, hidden outside their encampment, as long as it takes--all night, if need be--until their leader shows his miserable face.

And then you'll put an arrow right into his heart.


It's a crude plan. You'll die, of course---but your one hope is that without leadership, the goblins will fall apart and leave Lyestra alone.


Alright. Time to go.

action_results.action: Crawl through the grass towards the goblin camp
action_results.result:
You crawl stealthily through the hills.


Wind whips through the tall grass.


You can see the glimmer of torchlight to the north. Could it be the goblin camp?


You'll have to decide on a plan of action.

You crawl through the thick grass and reach the entrance of the camp!


There is a crude, makeshift wall surrounding the encampment. It was clearly built in a day, from mud and packed stone. Goblins are fast workers, even if they are sloppy.


At the entrance of the camp, there is a gap in the wall, an entryway that leads to and from the inner camp.


And through that opening, you can see details of the camp itself. Dozens of goblins mill about, sharpening weapons and grunting in their weird goblin language.


In the center of the camp, there is a stone chair. A blue-skinned man sits on the chair, examining his nails smugly. He wears a long, flowing cape.


Guarding the entryway are two goblin sentries. They're both small, about three feet, armed with spears and wearing rusty helmets and cheap armor.


You might be able to take them on....but without raising the alarm?

action_results.action: Shoot an arrow at one of the goblins
action_results.result:
You swiftly raise your crossbow, and fire a bolt at one of the goblins!


The bolt pierces him in the neck, and he goes down with a gurgle.


"GNGHHHGHRG GHRHG!!" The other goblin shouts. "INTRUDER!! TO ARMS!!"


You try to run, but you've given your position away. You're overwhelmed by goblins in seconds.


And they don't take you prisoner.

action_results.action: Sneak closer and take them out at close range
action_results.result:
You slither through the grass, drawing your knives.


The goblins are sleepy, and don't pay much attention to you at all as you get closer....closer...closer.....


SHIIIINK!


SHINK!


With twin slashes, you pierce both of the goblins with your daggers before they have the chance to utter a squeak.


They both hit the ground like twin sacks of flour.


The gateway is clear.

You are now inside of the goblin camp. You quickly find a tent to hide behind and consider your options.


You are now in the very heart of danger. There is no way that you're making it out of this camp alive.


But--you can try to take the leader down before you're killed.


You assumed the goblin leader is the man on the stone chair. If you can just make it to him....


But how?


You weigh your options. There are several siege towers not far from your location. You might be able to climb one and get a bird's eye view.


Or you could try to use the tents in the camp as cover.


Both options seem risky, but you have no choice now.

Alright.


You sprint madly over to the nearest siege tower, and miraculously, no one sees you.


You begin to climb the tower. A long, rickety ladder leads to the very top. From there, you might have a good shot at the general himself.


You are halfway up the ladder, when you look up and see a goblin.


He hasn't noticed you yet--he's climbing down the ladder, yawning, not paying any attention.


He's only a few rungs away from you......

action_results.action: Climb back down the ladder quickly!
action_results.result:
You try it, but the goblin sees you!


"INTRUDER!! STOP HIM!!!"


The call goes through the entire camp like wildfire. In seconds, you are surrounded by goblins.


And they don't take you prisoner.

action_results.action: Stab the goblin before he gets to you!
action_results.result:
You draw your knife, and plunge it into the goblin's back!


He squeals, and loses his grip on the ladder.


He falls several feet to the ground, where he lands with a hard SPLAT.


You hold your breath. Did anyone hear that?


Well, either way, you'd better hurry.


You finish the climb, and reach the very top of the siege tower. From here, you can see the entire camp.


"HEY!" A scratchy voice shouts.


A goblin stands at the top of the tower. He has a mottled appearance, and one of his eyes is swelled shut.


"What are you doing here??" He demands. His fingers clutch at a horn, attached to his belt.


You'd better think quick.

"Screw this," you mutter, and fire an arrow at the goblin.


"Grrrhh!!!" he howls, as the arrow pierces his shoulder.


He stumbles backwards, but before he falls, he raises the horn to his lips.


BRRRRUMMMMMMMMM


The horn is LOUD, WAY louder than you thought it could be.


You look down in horror.


Goblins are streaming out of their tents like a wild river.


They surround the tower. You can see them below, pointing up at you, gabbling wildly, aiming arrows at you.....


And then the arrows start flying.


You last about ten seconds.

You shoot the horn!


Good thinking, too. The arrow pierces the horn, and the goblin shrieks in pain as the arrow clips his hand as well.


You lunge forward, and give the goblin a mighty shove!


He stumbles backwards, plunging over the edge of the tower.


"Ahhhhhhhh--!!" he screams, and then hits the ground with a tremendous THUD.


Alright, that's him taken care of. But now you've got to get to the center of camp somehow.

The goblin's cry has awakened the camp.


Goblins stumble out of their tents, confused, still a bit sleepy, trying to figure out where the cry came from.


They're going to find you any minute.


You cast your eyes about the top of the tower, looking for anything that can help you, anything--


You see a thick coil of ropes, in one corner of the tower.


Great. That should help. You collect them.


You'd better think of something fast! The goblins will find you any minute.

You are standing at the top of the siege tower.

The goblins are searching for you.


You have a coil of ropes.

You start to climb down the ladder, but you stop once you've climbed a few rungs. If you go any lower, the goblins will see you for sure!


You climb back up.
Nope. Nothing here but dust. You got everything of value when you grabbed the ropes.

action_results.action: Fire an Arrow into the Center of Camp
action_results.result:
You aim carefully.....


You fire an arrow straight and true into the center of camp!


It hits a wooden post, where it sticks hard and fast. You can barely see it, sticking out of the post.


The blue-skinned man in the chair looks around, confused.


Now what?

action_results.action: Tie the Rope to an Arrow
action_results.result:
Okay, great. You tie the end of the rope to an arrow.


Now what?

You've been too slow.


The goblins find you!


In seconds, they're swarming up the tower, murder in their eyes.

action_results.action: Fire an Arrow into the Center of Camp
action_results.result:
You fire the rope into the center of camp.


It fires into a wooden post, taking the rope with it.


Huh. So much for your rope.


This is not gonna go well.

action_results.action: Tie the Rope to the Tower
action_results.result:
Great!


Now you have one end of the rope tied to the arrow, and the other end tied fast to the tower.


The goblins look up! They've seen you!!


Hurry!

action_results.action: Fire an Arrow into the Center of Camp
action_results.result:
The arrow flies hard and true, where it lands with a THUNK in a wooden post at the center of camp.


The blue-skinned man looks confused. He gazes about, searching for the source of the sound.


Meanwhile, the goblins have started swarming up the tower!


You see the first one poke his head over the edge of the platform.


Go!! NOW!!!

action_results.action: Slide down the rope to the center of camp!
action_results.result:
You grab the rope, in your hands, and begin to slide down it, just as the goblins reach the top of the tower!


Their hands clutch at you, swiping at your back and missing you by inches.


You zip down the rope, zooming towards the center of camp. You can see tents whooshing by as you hurtle towards the center, you can see the blue-skinned man on his throne look up in shock and surprise, as you careen wildly towards him....


Then you let go of the rope, and go tumbling into the center of camp.


You bolt to your feet, crossbow already drawn, already pointed at the general's heart.


Dozens of goblins surround you, their weapons outstretched, but you don't care.


You made it.

"NOBODY MOVE!!" you scream. You hold the crossbow steady.


The blue-skinned man raises an eyebrow.


"Well, well, well," he hisses. His eyes are serpentine. A forked tongue flickers from his lips. As he rises from his stone chair, his cape swirls dramatically.


"So you've come to face me, hm? Me. LARCASSIO?!"


What is it with this guy and saying his own name?


"Yeah, that's right," you say, grimly. "I've been dying to meet you. And now you're gonna be dying. But not to meet me. Just the regular kind of dying."


Dangit. That was your one chance to say something cool.


"Oh, my dear boy...." Larcassio says, "You do realize you'll be dead half a second after you pull that trigger...don't you?"


"Of course I know that," you say, "But I don't care. Maybe with you dead, Lyestra will have a fighting chance. It's not much, but it's all I can do."


"Dear me," Larcassio says, "So you don't care if you live or die. How noble. But....what about....."


He lazily raises a finger towards the sky. You follow his gaze.....looking up.....and your heart sinks.

High, high above the camp, attached to one of the siege towers, a cage swings freely in the open air.


And in that cage....


"Arakhan!!" A pair of gloved hands grip at the bars of the cage. "You're alive!! You made it!!"


You feel sick. You recognize the green cloak of your friend and fellow guard--


--It's Anaria.


"So....I, uh....caught the trail of this Larcassio creep," Anaria shouts down at you, "I--uh, I almost had him! But he--um, kinda got the jump on me." She grimaces. "Sorry, boss."


Larcassio chuckles.


"If you shoot me with that bolt, that cage goes crashing to the ground," Larcassio says smugly, "And do you think your dearest friend Anaria could survive such a drop? I think not."


"HEY! Boss! What's he saying down there?!" Anaria shouts down at you, "Whatever it is, don't listen to 'im! Kill the slimeball!!"


Your hand falters. You don't know if you can do it.


"Oh bother," Larcassio says. His forked tongue flickers. "It seems that we're at a bit of a stalemate now, aren't we? I can't kill you, because then I might end up dead. And you can't kill me, because you're a sad excuse for a man. Whatever shall we do?"

"Alright," you say. You point at him. "Let's make a deal. You. Me. One on one. A duel of honor."


Larcassio cocks his head.


"A pretty desperate attempt..." he says, "I have you surrounded, you know...."


"Yeah, and that's SO brave of you, isn't it?" you say, "You're the mighty Larcassio, right? Pretty tough when you've got a hundred goblins backing you up. But if you're too scared..."


"SCARED??" Larcassio bellows. He marches forward, and his cape swirls across the ground. He gets so close to you that the tip of your crossbow bolt digs into his chest. He's face to face with you. "I'm not scared of ANYTHING!" he proclaims.


He holds his hands high in the air.


"I burned your puny little village to the ground! And I will kill you easily, boy!" He extends his arm. "My fencing sword, if you please!"


The goblins scramble.


"NOW!!" he roars.


Finally, a wizened goblin hands Larcassio an elegant sword. The hilt is flamboyant, encrusted with diamonds and pearls. The blade itself gleams brightly, reflecting the torchlight.


"Let's end this embarrassing display of resistance, shall we?" Larcassio mocks, and slashes his sword at the ground. "And then, we'll get what we really came for...."


"Fine," you say, "But if I win, Anaria and I go free."


Larcassio laughs hysterically.


"En garde!" he cries.

You grab a fencing sword from the ground and defend yourself awkwardly.


Larcassio paces back and forth, watching you and smirking.


"This will be even easier than I thought..." he mutters.


The goblins have encircled the two of you, and they are cheering Larcassio on.


You frantically try to remember everything you know about fencing.....it isn't much.

You and Larcassio square off.


A moment passes, both of you waiting to see what the other will do.


Then, Larcassio lunges at you, blade outstretched!

Larcassio's blade plunges into you.....


The world is spinning.


You see a pair of snake like eyes, and a sharp-toothed grin, and everything fades away......

A *clink* as Larcassio's blade is parried away. He grunts and retreats quickly, defending himself.


"Good," Larcassio said, "Let's keep this interesting."


Larcassio is very near, defending himself.

You swiftly attack Larcassio!


He bats your sword away with an expert parry.


He circles you, and then lunges at you, aiming for your neck.
You parry the blow once more, but this time, Larcassio is thrown slightly off balance, opening up for just a millisecond--

You try to set up an attack, but you're not in the right position to do that!


Larcassio regains his footing, and circles you once again.

You assume a defensive position.


The two of you hold your defensive stance.


"Come ON," Larcassio says, and you see his blade flash out towards you--

Assuming a defensive stance was the right call.


Larcassio didn't plan to attack, he only wanted to scare you.


Fortunately, you didn't fall for it.


"Thank goodness," Larcassio says, "At least I'm not dealing with a total amateur."

You try to parry, but it was a trick!


Larcassio was merely feinting towards you, and now you're off balance.


You stumble backwards, trying to put as much distance between him and you as you can.

You attempt to parry, but since Larcassio hasn't attacked you yet, you end up looking foolish.


Larcassio bursts into laughter.


"What do you think you're doing?" he asks.


The two of you go back to circling.

You riposte, and slash your sword across Larcassio's arm.


"GAH!!" Larcassio screams, as he watches the blade strike across his flesh. Blue blood begins to pool and run down his arm, staining the blade.


He looks at you with hatred in his eyes.


"Oh, so you'd like to play ROUGH, huh?" he says.

Larcassio is sweating a bit. He watches you carefully.


"Come on, HERO!" he says, "Let's see you FIGHT!"


Larcassio lets loose with a flurry of attacks.


Looks like you're on the defensive--if only you'd paid better attention in fencing class!!

Larcassio stabs with a quick, sharp attack at your left shoulder.


Assume a defensive position, quick!

You knock Larcassio's sword away.


He follows up with another violent attack, this one aimed at your right leg.

You knock Larcassio's blade away.


"That was NOTHING!" you shout.


Larcassio swears and slashes straight down, right at your head!

You raise your sword high and block his attack a third time!


Then you follow it up with a blow of your own. You swing the hilt of your sword forward, bashing Larcassio in the face with it.


He reels one step backwards, stumbling and cursing.


Now's your chance! Go on the offensive!

You attack, but Larcassio had a parry ready for you. He blocks your attack and drives forward, plunging his sword towards your right lung.


Defend!

*Clink!*


You block the sword, and smash Larcassio in the face again. He staggers back a step, swearing and spitting.


This might be your only chance.

You attack again, but this time Larcassio is wise to your moves.


His sword is stabbing up into your chest before you even reach him.


"Good riddance," Larcassio hisses, and throws your body to the ground.

You lunge at Larcassio, but unfortunately you overshoot the mark. He's too close for that!


He dodges you easily, and slips his sword into your ribcage.


You grip your side as you collapse to the ground.


Everything goes dark.....

You feint, and Larcassio falls for it!


He tries to parry your nonexistent attack, and throws himself even more off balance. He staggers backwards a few more steps, trying to put distance between you.

You lunge, putting as much force into the blow as you can.


Larcassio is unprepared for the blow, and your momentum carries you straight forward, directly into his left shoulder.


The blade drives home, through his shoulder and out the other side. Dark blue blood gushes from his wounds.


"AGHHH!!!" he howls. "Who trained you?! Why aren't you dead yet?!"


"I'm just naturally lucky, I guess," you say.


With an inhuman howl, Larcassio drops his sword and tackles you. Your sword goes flying, and clatters to the ground.


Larcassio pins you to the dirt.


He starts punching you in the face viciously.


Amid the blows, you notice your crossbow, lying just barely within reach. You might be able to grab it....

action_results.action: Stretch your hand towards the crossbow.....
action_results.result:
Your fingers crawl across the dirt, ever closer to the crossbow.


You try to maintain consciousness as Larcassio keeps hammering away at your face.


"I will NOT be humiliated by you," Larcassio swears, "Not by some TWO-BIT, BACKWATER human!!"

You stretch just a little more....success! Your fingers curl around the crossbow.


You have one shot!

You swing the crossbow up and shoot at Larcassio's head.


With lightning reflexes, he dodges the bolt, and it goes sailing harmlessly off into the stratosphere.


"One last desperate attempt, hm?" Larcassio says, "Well, I'd be disappointed if you didn't try otherwise. Now, I must say....all this fighting has really worked up my appetite."


The last thing you see is Larcassio's mouth splitting open like an anaconda's, and then you feel razor sharp teeth dig into your neck.

Your fingers are trembling and bloodstained.


Larcassio twitches for a minute when he sees the crossbow, ducking his head....but you don't aim it at him.


You swing it around and point it at a nearby torch, burning brightly.


*click*


The crossbow bolt fires, splitting the wood of the torch neatly.


The torch plummets to the ground, quickly igniting a nearby tent.


"Wha--?" Larcassio says. His attention is briefly turned from you.


You knee him in the chest.


"Ufffhhh!!" he croaks, and you shove his weight off of you. He collapses to the ground and lies still.


Goblins begin to sprint about, gabbling and shrieking. The flames are spreading rapidly. Tents ignite in seconds. The goblins scream and try to put out the blazes, but the camp is rapidly turning into an enormous bonfire.


You look around rapidly, and you see the siege tower that Anaria is hanging from. The flames have spread to the tower, and are starting to lick the base of the wood.


"Don't worry about me, boss!' Anaria cries, "You did your job! Get outta here!"


"Not a chance!" you call up to her.

You sprint to the base of the siege tower. The goblins, for the most part, are wildly scrambling, and pay little attention to you. You hoist yourself up the wooden ladder.


You reach the top of the tower. Anaria's cage is tied to a jutting wooden outcropping. You get on your belly and shimmy along the outcropping.


You finally reach the cage, and swing your weight down. You start kicking at the door.


"You came back for me," Anaria says.


"Never leave a guard behind," you say. "Stand back."


Anaria retreats to the far end of the cage. You rear back, and give a tremendous kick to the door.


It explodes open. You extend your hand.


"Alright, come with me!" you shout. Anaria grabs your hand, and the two of you scramble back up to the wooden outcropping, balancing on it precariously.


It's no wider than a tree branch. You breathe deeply.


Imagine that it's solid ground, you will yourself, don't think about the height...


Like an idiot, you look down. From this height, the goblins look like a mass of green ants, scurrying to and fro as they flee the camp in a panic.


"Anaria!" you shout. The roar of the goblins below is deafening, and the billowing smoke and heat is causing you to tear up. "Let's get back to the siege tower before..."


Out of the smoke, you see a thin figure emerge.

"Everything was going so well today," Larcassio says.


He's covered in scratches, sweat, and his own blue blood. He's breathing heavily, and his snake eyes flicker in the smoke.


"And then YOU happened." He strides forward, walking on the wooden beam as though it were a paved road. He has tremendous balance. You wobble slightly.


Larcassio draws his rapier and prods you backwards, towards the edge of the outcropping. Even from this height, you can see the glint of your weapons, lying uselessly on the ground below.


You look back for Anaria--but she's gone.


You hear the groaning creak of wood.

You lunge at Larcassio, but you have no weapons. He simply laughs and pokes at you with his rapier.


"You have NOTHING, boy," Larcassio says, "You just keep backing up, now. Or, you can end it quickly and jump."


You catch a glimpse of green. Anaria's cloak.


She's UNDERNEATH the wooden beam, crawling upside down like a monkey, getting closer to Larcassio with every second.


You lock eyes, and she motions you to be quiet.


Larcassio takes another step towards you, his hair slick with sweat.


"Go on...." he says.

"Tell me something, Larcassio," you say, "Have you ever heard of the Stone Lions of Trapper's Glen?"


"You're stalling," Larcassio says, "Stop wasting my time...unless you'd rather die by the sword?"


"No, give me this," you say, "It's important. See, the Stone Lions are a bit of a legend in these parts. They worship riddles. They think that a riddle can tell you which person is the better man."


"We already know which of us is the better man," Larcassio sneers.


"Do we? Cause up to now, it seems like sort of a tie. Wouldn't you like to know for sure?"


You flick your gaze down, and see Anaria, closing in on Larcassio. She's only inches away, but if he were to look down.....


"So you want one last challenge?" Larcassio muses. The flames are billowing ever higher. It's going to be a miracle if any of you make it out of this alive.


"That's right!" you yell, trying to keep his attention on you at all costs, "I ask you a riddle. If you guess it, you're better than I am."


"EASY," Larcassio roars, "Give me your best shot."

You close your eyes and take a deep breath.


You can picture Anaria, crawling across the beam, positioning herself under Larcassio's feet....


You open your eyes.


I am the glue that binds heaven to earth,

Sea to shore,

And raindrop to soil-

Challenge me, and I shall always prevail

Defy me, and I grow deadlier still.

For I bring all men down to the same level.

What am I?


Larcassio's eyes flicker wildly.


He doesn't know, you think. You catch a glimpse of Anaria. She's made it! She's directly underneath Larcassio. His cape billows around him, flickering just in and out of Anaria's grasp.


"All men...the same..." Larcassio gnashes his teeth. "The same--gah!! I--"


"Time's running out, Larcassio," you say, "What am I?"


Larcassio grips the sides of his head and howls in frustration.


"I---I DON'T KNOW!!!" he screams.


Anaria's hand clamps around the end of Larcassio's billowing cape.


"Gravity," you say.


Anaria yanks once, hard.

"AHHHHHHHHH!!!!" Larcassio's final scream is a peal that echoes throughout the entire camp.


You watch his body pinwheel through space, falling down the length of the siege tower until landing with a thud on the earth, thirty feet below.


Anaria swings her body up, as smoothly as a gymnast, and balances on the top of the beam.


"Sorry, boss," Anaria says, "I guess I stole your revenge, huh?"


"No time to worry about that," you say, "We gotta get off this tower!!!"


The two of you link hands and, using each other for balance, sprint across the beam.


You've only just made it across when the beam splinters and cracks, falling to the earth below in a shower of wood and smoke.


"Run--" you say, panting for breath. The siege tower has gone up in flames. Keeping low to the ground, the two of you slide down the ladder, burning your hands on the wood.


A few feet from the bottom, the siege tower begins to collapse, and you both leap to the earth, rolling and thudding across the ground.


The tower collapses in a magnificent display. Ash and flame burst into the sky.


You and Anaria clamber to your feet.


"Not bad for a day's work," Anaria says.

You and Anaria stumble through the camp, often leaning on each other for support.


You're both coughing wildly from the smoke that fills the air. Everything is smokey confusion. The goblins nearly trip over you in their haste to find safety.


They've stopped caring about either of you long ago.


Finally, you and Anaria clear the boundaries of the camp.


Together, you traverse the hills back to town, leaving the wreckage of the goblin camp far behind.


You've journeyed halfway across the hills when you see a cluster of villagers, running over the hills to greet you!


Friendly faces, smiling, arms outstretched.


Joad leads the pack, smiling for the first time in ages.


"We saw the smoke, captain," he says. He lets you lean your weight on him. You take a load off your ankle, which feels much better. You must have twisted it back at the camp.


Your friend Lodan rushes towards Anaria, catching her and keeping her steady.


"Alright, easy does it, you two," Joad says, "Let's get you back home."


In less than an hour, you and Anaria are back in the town of Lyestra.


Everything is foggy. You feel hands tucking you tightly into a warm bed, and then the world goes dark.


It's been a long day.

"Listen, Larcassio," you say, "This whole siege tower is about to go up in flames. And that means we go up in flames, too. You're just going to die with me unless we both escape right now!"


"Do you think that MATTERS?" Larcassio spits, "I'm dead already. Gremgrawler will dice me into pieces when he finds out I let you burn this camp to the ground."


"Who?" you ask, but Larcassio waves your question away. "March," he says, "Or you can save time and jump."


You catch a glimpse of green. Anaria's cloak.


She's UNDERNEATH the wooden beam, crawling upside down like a monkey, getting closer to Larcassio with every second.


You lock eyes, and she motions you to be quiet.


Larcassio takes another step towards you, his hair slick with sweat.


"Go on...." he says.

You protect your right shoulder, but that's not where Larcassio was aiming!


Larcassio's blade plunges into you.....


The world is spinning.


You see a pair of snake like eyes, and a sharp-toothed grin, and everything fades away......

You protect your lower inside region, but that's not where Larcassio was aiming....


Larcassio's blade plunges into you.....


The world is spinning.


You see a pair of snake like eyes, and a sharp-toothed grin, and everything fades away......

You feint forwards, doing a 'fake attack,' but Larcassio isn't fooled. He continues to watch you carefully.


"You'll have to do better than that..." he says.

You can only attempt a riposte after you've succesfully parried!


You end up looking foolish. Larcassio chuckles.


"This is going to be too easy...." he smirks.


The two of you go back to circling.

As you're flailing, you recall that a 'remise' is a follow-through attack, which can only be attempted after a lunge.


You end up looking a bit silly.


Larcassio rolls his eyes.


"Please, give me some sort of challenge," he demands.


The two of you go back to circling.

action_results.action: Tie the Rope to the Tower
action_results.result:
Okay. The rope is firmly tied to the tower.


Now what?

action_results.action: Tell him you're here for a routine safety inspection
action_results.result:
"Well, buddy, I'm not gonna mince words," you say, confidently. "Gruk, gruk's your name, right?"


"Yes, my name Gruk." The goblin says, confused, "How you know that?"


You decline to mention that almost ninety percent of goblins are named Gruk.


"Name's Arakhan. Routine safety inspection," you say, extending your hand.


Gruk stares at your outstretched hand.


"Look, lemme tell ya, pal," you say, "These siege towers are not up to code. You see this?"


You stand near the edge of the tower and wave your arms.


"That's a thirty foot drop, pal. You're gonna need safety railing for all of these bad boys. Or I'm gonna have to shut down this whole operation. And don't think I didn't notice you're not wearing a hard hat. We take safety seriously on these big siege operations."


Gruk scratches his head, confused.


"Hm...." he says. He's clearly thinking very hard. Then he snaps his fingers, triumphantly.


"Hold on second," Gruk says, smiling craftily at you, "If you safety inspector....where your inspection permit?"

"Oh, uh," you pat at your body frantically. "I must have left them in my....my other trousers."


"You try good," Gruk says, raising his bow, "But you forget one thing....Gruk not know what trousers are."


You only have a second to feel infuriated at the illogicality of this moment.


An arrow pierces your heart.


This is probably the silliest way to die, you think, and that's really saying somethi-

You storm forward, putting on your best show of blustering confidence.


"Well, I never!" you shout, "In thirty-five years, I have NEVER come across anything like this."


Gruk backs down, cowed.


"Oh, um," he says, "Gruk am sorry."


"To think, I'm getting questioned by a grunt like you! The sheer nerve. You know, I could have your hide. Worse, I could have your JOB."


Gruk gulps.


You gesture to the edge of the siege tower, and Gruk toddles over to where you're standing. He peers down at the ground below.


"Now, I'm glad we had this little talk," you say. You smack Gruk on the back triumphantly.


"Whughh--whuh---" the momentum of the smack sends Gruk pinwheeling forward.


He loses his balance and tumbles over the edge of the tower!


"Aggghhhhhhh---" he screams, until his cry is cut short by a hard thud. You look down at the ground far below, and wince.


"Hm. Should've invested in safety railings," you say.

Alright. Time to put your stealth skills to the test.

action_results.action: Go East, higher into the hills
action_results.result:
You ascend the hills to the east.


From this high vantage point, you can see the goblin camp!


It lies below, at the base of the valley. Hundreds of goblins are milling about, grabbling with each other and preparing for war.


And there, in the center of the encampment, there is a stone chair. A thin, blue-skinned man sits in the throne, looking smug. He wears a long billowing cape.

Think quick!
